item.title: Physics Wasn't Waiting for Better Evidence. It Was Waiting for Permission.
item.description:
In 2019, Google published a paper in Nature.

Four years of research. Ten million dollars. A multi-institutional team — University of British Columbia, MIT, University of Maryland, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory — with no particular stake in defending the reputation of Pons and Fleischmann. They used modern instrumentation. They reported their methods. They were thorough.

They found no excess heat.

That sentence travels far and fast. “Google couldn’t replicate cold fusion.” What the paper actually says is: our apparatus was not sensitive enough to detect small heat effects, and we identified three specific areas warranting further investigation — higher deuterium loading, more sensitive calorimetry, and better materials characterization of heavily loaded palladium. The paper’s final word is not “impossible.” The paper’s final word is “here is what should be done next.”

item.title: The Word Died in 1989. The Experiment Didn't.
item.description:
The press conference was the crime. Not the science - the press conference.

March 23, 1989. Martin Fleischmann and Stanley Pons stand in front of cameras at the University of Utah and announce they’ve achieved nuclear fusion at room temperature. In a glass jar. With palladium electrodes and heavy water. The physics establishment’s reaction landed somewhere between “excuse me?” and “how dare you.”

Nobody cracks down on a failed experiment. What they cracked down on was the venue. You don’t announce nuclear fusion without peer review. You don’t do it at a press conference. You don’t do it before independent replication is in. These were genuine violations of genuine norms and the physics community had a real point.
